edge: Barfi is a deaf-mute young man based in Darjeeling.
The film focuses on Barfi, who is based in Darjeeling but also spends time in Kolkata.
Barfi has a relationship with Shruti.
Barfi also has a relationship with Jhilmil, who is autistic.
The film is set in Darjeeling and Kolkata of the 1970s.
Ranbir Kapoor plays the role of Barfi in the film.
Priyanka Chopra plays the character of Jhilmil, who is autistic.
Ileana D'Cruz makes her Hindi film debut playing the character of Shruti in the film.
Anurag Basu wrote and directed the film Barfi!
The film Barfi! was backed by UTV Motion Pictures.
Barfi and Murphy are two names for the same person, who is an optimistic, street-smart, charming young man who was born deaf and mute to a couple in Darjeeling.
Jungbahadur raised Barfi alone while working as a chauffeur.
Barfi is chased by Inspector Sudhanshu Dutta, a local police officer because he cuts lampposts and plays practical jokes.

Barfi meets Shruti Ghosh, a gorgeous, educated young girl who has just arrived in Darjeeling. They fall in love with each other, but Shruti's mother dissuades her from pursuing Barfi because he could not take care of her with his disabilities and lack of money.
Shruti Ghosh is engaged to Ranjeet Sengupta and is due to get married in three months, but Barfi is immediately smitten with Shruti.
Shruti unwillingly takes her mother's advice and marries Ranjeet Sengupta, cutting off all contact with Barfi.
The film 'Barfi!' was selected as India's official entry for the Best Foreign Language Film nomination for the 85th Academy Awards.
Barfi! won several awards and nominations at various award ceremonies across India.

Barfi! received a leading 12 nominations including Best Director (Basu), Best Actress (Chopra) and Best Supporting Actress (D'Cruz), and won a leading 7 awards including Best Film, Best Actor (Kapoor), Best Female Debut (D'Cruz) and Best Music Director (Pritam).
Barfi is compelled to somehow raise the amount of ₹7000 for his father's surgery due to his kidney failure.
Barfi's attempt to rob a local bank is unsuccessful, resulting in Barfi contemplating the kidnapping of Jhilmil Chatterjee for a ransom to raise money for his father's surgery.
Barfi's childhood friend and wealthy heiress of her grandfather's fortune, Jhilmil Chatterjee, is kidnapped by someone else before Barfi can carry out his plan.
Jhilmil's father, Durjoy Chatterjee, files a police report and arranges a ransom of ₹50,000 as demanded for his daughter's safe return.
Barfi discovers that Jhilmil has already been kidnapped and decides to help her escape from Inspector Dutta and the police in pursuit.

After collecting the ransom money, Barfi's father dies just as he makes the hospital payment. Barfi is dejected and tries to leave Jhilmil at the village of her caretaker, but she refuses to leave him.
The two soon move to Kolkata, where Barfi assumes responsibility for Jhilmil and takes care of her.

Six years later, Barfi and Shruti reunite by chance in Kolkata. Shruti is unhappy with her marriage with Ranjeet, and rekindles her friendship with Barfi, much to the chagrin of the lovestruck Jhilmil.

Barfi is deeply affected by Jhilmil's loss and finds living with Shruti unfulfilled. In a plot twist, both discover that Jhilmil is alive all along, and the two kidnappings were fabricated to embezzle money from Jhilmil's trust fund.
Her father colluded with caretakers from her childhood foster home to fabricate both kidnappings and faked her death, so that she could return to her special-care home away from her alcoholic mother.

Later, media reported that Asin was approached to play the role of the narrator, replacing Kaif. However, Asin was never signed to the project.
Media reported that no other actress wanted to sign for the film because according to them, Chopra's part was stronger.

The makers of the film kept Priyanka's character under wraps in the trailers to increase curiosity among audiences and reveal it only around the release of the film.
UTV Motion Pictures created a YouTube application called The Flavour of Barfi, featuring Ranbir Kapoor as his character from the film and allowing users to type actions for him to act out.

On September 12, 2012, British manufacturer Murphy Radio claimed that the Murphy baby logo from its 1970s print advertisements was used in Barfi! without permission. Producer Siddharth Roy Kapur stated that a legal notice had been received from Murphy, but the intention behind showcasing the brand in question was positive.

After the film's release, several blogs and social media websites accused director Anurag Basu of plagiarism. Videos showing side-by-side comparisons with Hollywood films like Cops, The Adventurer, City Lights, Singin' in the Rain, Project A, The Notebook and Benny & Joon were also uploaded to YouTube.
The background music in Barfi! was accused of being copied from the French film Amélie by music director Pritam.

node_2: original plot, screenplay, characters and situations
edge: Director Anurag Basu defended the film by stating that he was inspired by these works and that Barfi! contained an original plot, screenplay, characters and situations. He also mentioned that he was paying homages to Keaton and Chaplin.

The selection of Barfi! for Best Foreign Language Film at the Oscars faced criticism due to plagiarism allegations, but Oscar selection committee chief Manju Borah defended the film by saying that it deserved to be sent outside and was chosen after several rounds of discussions.
Pratim D. Gupta described Barfi! as 'no story and all storytelling'.

edge: According to Pratim D. Gupta, Barfi!'s brilliance comes from being orchestrated by a director who has shown death the door.

Rediff.com mentioned that Pritam's music added a 'silent-era charm' to Barfi!.
Raja Sen wrote about Barfi!'s intriguing back-and-forth narrative.
Raja Sen stated that 'Barfi! goes south towards the end'.
Rajeev Masand of CNN-IBN stated that Barfi! had the potential to be great cinema, but as it stands it's a respectable film that's still better than a lot else you're likely to see.
Anupama Chopra writing for Hindustan Times stated that Barfi! was a singularly frustrating experience, although there was so much to like.
Namrata Joshi of Outlook stated that the flashback within flashback narrative in Barfi! appeared much too crafted and self-consciously gorgeous, and felt eminently facile and plastic.
Namrata Joshi of Outlook stated that the flashback within flashback narrative in Barfi! included a pointless thriller twist.

Upon its release, Barfi! started strongly at multiplexes throughout India, with around 80–90% occupancy.
Barfi! grossed ₹85.6 million (US$1.0 million) on its opening day.
Its second day saw an increase of around 35% occupancy and collected ₹115 million (US$1.4 million).
Barfi! collected ₹565 million (US$6.8 million) nett, in its first week.
Barfi! earned ₹32.5 million (US$390,000) despite the release of Heroine.
Barfi! earned ₹150 million (US$1.8 million) in its second weekend.
The film's takings rose to ₹158 million (US$1.9 million) nett, in the third week.
During its cinematic release period, Barfi! earned a gross total of ₹1.06 billion (US$13 million) in India.
The all-India distributor share of the film was ₹500 million (US$6.0 million).
The film went on to gross ₹1.75 billion (US$21 million) worldwide.
Barfi earned around ₹124 million (US$1.5 million) in its opening weekend, slightly exceeding Raajneeti – which had collected ₹116 million.
